title: Is it just me or does the assassin rework seem more counterintuitive?
body:
The whole point of the assassin rework was to add even more counterplay than the loads there already were. The ones asking for this were mostly the bad players who didn't already know or want to bother learning the pre-existing counterplay. The rework succeeded in that sense.

However, the general approach was by increasing the burst times with massive delays so that there was plenty of time to react to said assassination attempt. In return, the damage for actually landing said combo means it would hit far harder.

When the ones complaining in the first place are the ones who are fairly bad, it seems like the only thing that would happen is the bad players would get hurt even worse while better players would generally just laugh and pick a mage instead of an assassin, and then play at their high-tier of play.

If a high-tier player (outside of the top like Faker or such) played just about any assassin (excluding LeBlanc, Kha'Zix, and/or Rengar, possibly Katarina?), they probably would not get very far, due to how incredibly long the potential reaction time is, as well as being able to avoid the combo's main damage altogether for most of the current reworked assassins fairly easily.

Like, yes, congratulations, they are more potentially complex and potentially rewarding, but outside of a few exceptions, almost all of them would be completely useless in the face of a half-competent player. On the other hand, the lower-tier players who already can't dodge skillshots or respect kill zones/pressure timers and cooldowns would just get stomped even harder, and then probably complain even more.

EDIT: If you're going to downvote, at least bother posting why you disagree. Jeez.

I think another purpose of the Assassin rework that nobody's recognizing is that your _choice_ of assassin is more important now.  I'm not an Assassin player, but I'll try to think of some decent examples...

Zed's ultimate now scales with the AD of his target - he was already great against Jhin, able to reliably assassinate him, and is now even more rewarded for counterpicking appropriately.  However, as he's now balanced around that potential, he's weaker when he's forced to prioritize AP and utility targets like Cassiopeia and Soraka.  

Talon excels at assassinating targets who need foresight to survive assassinations, like Caitlyn and Jhin (who partially rely on traps), because he has a reliable gapcloser and can attack from unpredictable angles.  

Katarina mobility lets her excel against skillshot based peel, while being as vulnerable as ever to targeted CC.

Kha'zix excels against isolated targets, making him invaluable in skirmishes and weaker in full-on teamfights.

Etc etc.  Assassins were reworked to have counterplay in general, but also to give them strengths and weaknesses in terms of _who_ they can reliably assassinate.  The delayed damage on their kits also means that a snowballing Assassin can usually assassinate their targets while holding their escape tools (Rengar's W, Katarina's W, Talon's wall jump if he doesn't use it to enter a fight), but can choose to sacrifice those tools for more reliable assassination if they're even or behind.

It's preseason, so Riot has a lot of tuning to do, but I'm calling it a success as things start to settle down.

He's stronger when he can do so, but weaker when his priority target is non-AD, a la Cassiopeia or Soraka.  This makes him a counterpick to AD-heavy teams (AD midlaners like Yasuo, melee carries like Fiora) and ADCs that prioritize AD (like Jhin, as opposed to Vayne).

As Zed stands now, he's rewarded for prioritizing AD Champions, and punished when he can't.  This logically makes him better against teams with more AD Champions, especially ones that prioritize stacking AD.  It gives him a niche that he didn't have before.
